favorites.name: Joan Halifax: Compassion and the true meaning of e
favorites.embeddedLink: <iframe src="https://embed-ssl.ted.com/talks/joan_halifax.html" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" webkitAllowFullScreen mozallowfullscreen allowFullScreen></iframe>

speaker.name: Joan Halifax
speaker.bio: Known for her compassionate work with the terminally ill, Joan Halifax is a driving force of socially engaged Buddhism.nFull bio
speaker.description: Buddhist roshi Joan Halifax works with people at the last stage of life (in hospice and on death row). She shares what she\'s learned about compassion in the face of death and dying, and a deep insight into the nature of empathy.

favorites.name: Emily Balcetis: Why some people find exercise hard
favorites.embeddedLink: <iframe src="https://embed-ssl.ted.com/talks/emily_balcetis_why_some_people_find_exercise_harder_than_others.html" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" webkitAllowFullScreen mozallowfullscreen allowFullScreen></iframe>

speaker.name: Emily Balcetis
speaker.bio: Social psychologist Emily Balcetis explores perception, motivation, goal-setting and decision-making from conscious and nonconscious levels.nFull bio
speaker.description: Why do some people struggle more than others to keep off the pounds? Social psychologist Emily Balcetis shows research that addresses one of the many factors: Vision. In an informative talk, she shows how when it comes to fitness, some people quite literally see the world differently from others â€”

favorites.name: Jae Rhim Lee: My mushroom burial suit
favorites.embeddedLink: <iframe src="https://embed-ssl.ted.com/talks/jae_rhim_lee.html" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" webkitAllowFullScreen mozallowfullscreen allowFullScreen></iframe>

speaker.name: Jae Rhim Lee
speaker.bio: Artist and TED Fellow Jae Rhim Lee re-imagines the relationships between the body and the world. Full bio
speaker.description: Here\'s a powerful provocation from artist Jae Rhim Lee. Can we commit our bodies to a cleaner, greener Earth, even after death? Naturally â€” using a special burial suit seeded with pollution-gobbling mushrooms. Yes, this just might be the strangest TEDTalk you\'ll ever see ...

recents.name: Beverly + Dereck Joubert: Life lessons from big ca
recents.embeddedLink: <iframe src="https://embed-ssl.ted.com/talks/beverly_dereck_joubert_life_lessons_from_big_cats.html" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" webkitAllowFullScreen mozallowfullscreen allowFullScreen></iframe>

speaker.name: Beverly + Dereck Joubert
speaker.bio: Documentary filmmakers Beverly and Dereck Joubert have worked to conserve wildlife for more than 25 years. As National Geographic Explorers in Residence, the couple influences public policy and perceptions.nFull bio
speaker.description: Beverly + Dereck Joubert live in the bush, filming and photographing lions and leopards in their natural habitat. With stunning footage (some never before seen), they discuss their personal relationships with these majestic animals â€” and their quest to save the big cats from human threats.

recents.name: Al Gore: Averting the climate crisis
recents.embeddedLink: <iframe src="https://embed-ssl.ted.com/talks/al_gore_on_averting_climate_crisis.html" width="560" height="420" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" webkitAllowFullScreen mozallowfullscreen allowFullScreen></iframe>

speaker.name: Al Gore
speaker.bio: Once the US Vice President, then star of An Inconvenient Truth, now Nobel Peace Prize winner, Al Gore found a way to focus the world's attention on climate change. In doing so, he has invented a new medium â€” the Keynote movie â€” and reinvented himself.nFull bio
speaker.description: With the same humor and humanity he exuded in An Inconvenient Truth, Al Gore spells out 15 ways that individuals can address climate change immediately, from buying a hybrid to inventing a new, hotter \"brand name\" for global warming.

recents.name: Al Gore: New thinking on the climate crisis
recents.embeddedLink: <iframe src="https://embed-ssl.ted.com/talks/al_gore_s_new_thinking_on_the_climate_crisis.html" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" webkitAllowFullScreen mozallowfullscreen allowFullScreen></iframe>

speaker.name: Al Gore
speaker.bio: Once the US Vice President, then star of An Inconvenient Truth, now Nobel Peace Prize winner, Al Gore found a way to focus the world's attention on climate change. In doing so, he has invented a new medium â€” the Keynote movie â€” and reinvented himself.nFull bio
speaker.description: In this brand-new slideshow (premiering on TED.com), Al Gore presents evidence that the pace of climate change may be even worse than scientists recently predicted. He challenges us to act.

recents.name: Adam Ostrow: After your final status update
recents.embeddedLink: <iframe src="https://embed-ssl.ted.com/talks/adam_ostrow_after_your_final_status_update.html" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" webkitAllowFullScreen mozallowfullscreen allowFullScreen></iframe>

speaker.name: Adam Ostrow
speaker.bio: As editor in chief at Mashable, Adam Ostrow covers the tech, trends and people driving the evolution of the Web. Full bio
speaker.description: Many of us have a social media presence â€” a virtual personality made up of status updates, tweets and connections, stored in the cloud. Adam Ostrow asks a big question: What happens to that personality after you\'ve died? Could it ... live on?

watchlist.name: Kees Moeliker: How a dead duck changed my life
watchlist.embeddedLink: <iframe src="https://embed-ssl.ted.com/talks/kees_moeliker_how_a_dead_duck_changed_my_life.html" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" webkitAllowFullScreen mozallowfullscreen allowFullScreen></iframe>

speaker.name: Kees Moeliker
speaker.bio: Kees Moeliker writes and speaks about natural history, especially birds and remarkable animal behavior, as well as improbable research and science-communication-with-a-laugh.nFull bio
speaker.description: One afternoon, Kees Moeliker got a research opportunity few ornithologists would wish for: A flying duck slammed into his glass office building, died, and then â€¦ what happened next would change his life. [Note: Contains graphic images and descriptions of sexual behavior in animals.]
